thread.title: Larry David's Sanders joins 'SNL' impersonations hall of fame
thread.title_full: Larry David's Sanders joins 'SNL' impersonations hall of fame

title: Larry David's Sanders joins 'SNL' impersonations hall of fame
text:
Larry David played Bernie Sanders on "SNL" Others have also done great political impersonations (CNN) Larry David may have been born to play Bernie Sanders . The "Curb Your Enthusiasm" star nailed it Saturday during a "Saturday Night Live" skit parodying the CNN Democratic debate . As Democratic candidate Sanders, he quickly "dialed it up to 10" and spouted such quips as "I don't have a super PAC. I don't even have a backpack." 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos Actress recently Kate McKinnon caught the notice of the political and entertainment worlds with her parody of Hillary Clinton, portraying her as a calculating and power-hungry politician. Click through to see the storied history of SNL and political parody: Hide Caption 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos Actress Amy Poehler, left, also played Hillary Clinton in several "Saturday Night Live" skits. Hide Caption 2 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos President Bill Clinton, left, laughs with lookalike Darrell Hammond of "Saturday Night Live" at the 53rd annual dinner of the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association in 1997. Hide Caption 3 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos Singer Miley Cyrus, right, played Michele Bachmann in a "Saturday Night Live" Digital Short parody of her song "We Can't Stop" about the federal government shutdown in 2013. Hide Caption 4 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos Actress Tina Fey's parody of Sarah Palin, left, on "Saturday Night Live" became a favorite during the 2008 elections. Hide Caption 5 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos Actor Jason Sudeikis, right, created Joe Biden's "Saturday Night Live" alter ego during the 2012 elections during a skit about the vice presidential debate. Hide Caption 6 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos "Saturday Night Live" often writes skits mocking presidential debates soon after they happened. Pictured from left: Mitt Romney, Barack Obama, Jason Sudeikis and Jay Pharoah from the 2012 election. Hide Caption 7 of 8 8 photos: Politicians and their SNL alter egos "Saturday Night Live" aired its own presidential debate for the 2004 election with Seth Meyers, left, as John Kerry and Will Forte as President George W. Bush. Hide Caption 8 of 8 David's version of Sanders brings to mind some of the other great political impersonations "SNL" has blessed us with over the years. Here are just a few: Tina Fey as Sarah Palin Fey so embodied the spirit of the former Alaska governor who aspired to be vice president that there are videos on the web matching her version of Sarah Palin up with the real one. It's pretty uncanny. Read More Dana Carvey as George H.W. Bush Carvey is so funny as George H. W. Bush that long after he was a cast member on "SNL" (he left the show in 1993), he's still asked to revive his impersonation from time to time. Phil Hartman as Bill Clinton The late Hartman was the master of voices and his portrayal of the 42nd president of the United States was a fan favorite during his eight seasons on "SNL" The actor left the late night show in 1994 and continued his voice work on "The Simpsons." Hartman was shot and killed in 1998 by his wife, Brynn Omdahl, who then committed suicide. Chevy Chase as Gerald Ford While the actor looked and sounded nothing like President Gerald Ford, Chase had the falling down mannerism dead to rights. He first started appearing in skits during "SNL's" first year on the air, 1975. Fans loved all of the bumbling.
Race to the White House More from Entertainment
